dt: {bc}to remove from a surface by usually repeated strokes of an edged instrument
{bc}to make (a surface) smooth or clean with strokes of an edged instrument or an abrasive
{bc}to damage or injure the surface of by contact with a rough surface
{bc}to draw roughly or noisily over a surface
{bc}to collect by or as if by scraping

dt.t: {wi}scrape{/wi} up the price of a ticket

dt: {bc}to move in sliding contact with a rough surface
{bc}to draw back the foot along the ground in making a bow
{bc}to make one's way with difficulty {bc}barely manage or succeed

dt.t: working two jobs and barely {it}scraping{/it} by

et: Middle English, from Old Norse {it}skrapa{/it}; akin to Old English {it}scrapian{/it} to scrape, Latin {it}scrobis{/it} ditch, Russian {it}skresti{/it} to scrape
shortdef: to remove from a surface by usually repeated strokes of an edged instrument
to make (a surface) smooth or clean with strokes of an edged instrument or an abrasive
to grate harshly over or against
